detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Support the children of incarcerated parents

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Today, one in 28 children has an incarcerated parent; almost one-fifth of these kids are under age four. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"One in nine Black children has an incarcerated parent. More than 5 million children have had a parent behind bars in the past. This separation takes a profound toll: Kids with incarcerated parents tend to underperform academically and are more likely to drop out of school. They’re at higher risk of experiencing anxiety, depression, post-traumatic stress disorder, and behavioral issues. Put simply, having an incarcerated parent is a traumatic experience. And, as research shows, traumatic experiences during childhood have lifelong effects.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must reduce the number of children with incarcerated parents by drastically reducing the number of parents incarcerated in the first place. Those children who experience parental incarceration can still thrive and succeed but they need the support to do so. We must create a world in which these children are provided with adequate community-based supports — affordable mental and physical health care, high-quality education, extracurricular activities, etc. — and the opportunity for ample in-person visits with their incarcerated parent. We must create a world in which families can remain together.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Read our policy recommendations.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Allow parents to spend the last 18 months of their sentence in programs and classes that prepare them for reentry and reunification with their children.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Codify the right to in-person, contact visits and substantially improve the visiting experience through innovative, people-centered changes to visiting facilities, procedures, and programming — without increasing corrections budgets.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Offer free video conferencing, email, and phone calls to allow children to stay connected with a parent in between in-person visits.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: End inhumane conditions in jails and prisons in the United States

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must radically reduce prison and jail populations while creating a new system premised on healing, accountability, rehabilitation, and respect for basic human rights.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must eliminate the practice of private companies profiting off the backs of people subject to the horrors of the criminal-legal system. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}
